item.title: “Gettin’ lucky” – implications for ventures on the frontiers.
item.description:
:::: entry-content ::: {style=“float: right; margin-left: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px;”} {decoding=“async” style=“border: 2px solid rgb(0, 0, 0);”}
[ Venturing on the Frontiers – A simple guide.
Originally uploaded by Michael Lewkowitz ]{style=“margin-top: 0px;font-size:0;”} :::

I wrote about the gist of this image here. Now I’m turning to the implications for venturers.

Quite simply the essence of venturing is a process. A process of creating spaces for things to happen (some call it ’luck’). The simpler and more accessible the space, the easier it is to get people engaged and get things done (some would say ’the luckier you get’).

item.title: Giddy-up: getting better on the frontier.
item.description: ::: entry-content Coming out of this first inquiry I’m left with new definitions for venture, venturing, and venturer and also a simplistic grouping that the process of venturing essentially requires agreement, action, and governance. It is important to note that these are a set of observations and interpretations that will continue to be evolved in practice. As such they represent a starting point for a concerted effort to ‘get better at venturing and investing on the frontiers’.
